title: Add frame-based control API for Lottie animations
body:
Adds frame-based seeking and playback control to `SKLottieView`. While time-based control via `Progress` property was already possible, frame-based operations are more intuitive for animation state management (e.g., switch animations, scrubbing).

## API Additions

**Properties (read-only)**
- `Fps` - Frame rate
- `FrameCount` - Total frames  
- `CurrentFrame` - Current frame (auto-updated)

**Methods**
- `SeekToFrame(int frameNumber, bool stopPlayback = false)` - Frame-based seeking with clamping
- `SeekToTime(TimeSpan time, bool stopPlayback = false)` - Time-based seeking
- `SeekToProgress(double progress, bool stopPlayback = false)` - Normalized seeking [0.0, 1.0]
- `Pause()` / `Resume()` - Explicit playback control

## Example Usage

```csharp
// Switch animation: toggle between on/off states
void ToggleSwitch(SKLottieView view)
{
    if (isOn)
        view.SeekToFrame(0, stopPlayback: true);  // Off state
    else
        view.SeekToFrame(view.FrameCount - 1, stopPlayback: true);  // On state
    isOn = !isOn;
}

// Scrub to 50%
view.SeekToProgress(0.5, stopPlayback: false);
```

## Implementation Notes

- `CurrentFrame` calculation: `(int)Math.Floor(progress.TotalSeconds * Fps)`
- `FrameCount` calculation: `(int)Math.Ceiling(duration.TotalSeconds * Fps)`
- All boundary values clamped to valid ranges
- Properties updated on animation load in `Reset()`

> [!WARNING]

<details>

<summary>Original prompt</summary>

> 
> ----
> 
> *This section details on the original issue you should resolve*
> 
> <issue_title>[FEATURE] Lottie play certain frames</issue_title>
> <issue_description>Be able to play to a certain frames. The lottie documentation has a [`goToAndStop`](https://airbnb.io/lottie/#/web?id=usage-1)
>  
> I'd like to create a switch using a lottie animation, but without this sort of functionality its impossible.
> https://lottiefiles.com/127464-animated-switch-ae-version
> </issue_description>
> 
> ## Comments on the Issue (you are @copilot in this section)
> 
> <comments>
> <comment_new><author>@mattleibow</author><body>
> I think all of these actions can be performed using properties:
> 
> - `IsAnimationEnabled` - `true` is start and `false` is stop
> - `Progress` - `TimeSpan` of the progress 
> - `Duration` - `TimeSpan` of the total time
> 
> If you want to get a percent progress then you can convert the `Duration` into `TotalSeconds` and then use that to get a percentage and convert back into a `TimeSpan` for the `Progress` property.</body></comment_new>
> </comments>
